subject: meta-ibm: network: Split ncsi-netlink service
commitMessage:
meta-ibm: network: Split ncsi-netlink service

Since P9 systems need only to stop the link failover, and P10 systems
need only to set the gigabit link speed, split the nsci-netlink
service into two and make it per-interface. Use the systemd network
check to make sure the link is up first. Use a helper script to fetch
the ifindex for the network interface

Signed-off-by: Eddie James <eajames@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I6558787a2234575b528864bb71705964a63c0498

CI failure was git clone failure for romulus
nit: please keep title to 50 chars and body to 72 chars
Any "Tested" statement or just relying on CI? Be good to verify P9 systems have fail over disabled and P10 systems have speed set as expected.
I've tested this on Rainier and Tacoma to make sure the service runs OK, but not sure how to test the failover/link speed. The actual ncsi-netlink commands should be identical to before
This is an improvement. I have a further suggestion.

This is a mess. Is there a reason to not create a shell script that does this?

ncsi-i210-link-speed %i

```
#!/bin/sh

IFPATH="/sys/class/net/$1/ifndex"

if [ ! -f "$IFPATH" ]; then
        echo Error: "$IFPATH" does not exist
fi

ncsi-netlink -x "$IFPATH" -p0 -c0 -o 00157200001

```

Alternatively, you could use the script like this:

ncsi-set -p0 -c0 -o 00157200001


```
#!/bin/sh

IFPATH="/sys/class/net/$1/ifndex"

if [ ! -f "$IFPATH" ]; then
        echo Error: "$IFPATH" does not exist
fi

ncsi-netlink -x "$IFPATH" "$@"
```
Still have a change coming to make the shell script Eddie?
We've been trying to get away from using this. But the fact we keep going back to it shows it's useful. So...fine with me at this point.
I couldn't work out how else to install the service such that it'd get started by network.target

we should write errors to stderr 
 >2
should we instead add this function into the ncsi-netlink executable with an alternate flag
No, I don't think it's worth the complexity?

all of the above are grouped by variable assignment but are disjointed repeated if statement via conditional append.

I wonder if it'd be better to group by platform?  
or maybe it's just which service to select and use that to build a common name later.   I find I have to follow closely which platform gets which script added with the current organization.

Well, the groupings follow other recipes that build up the systemd links for obmc-phosphor-systemd. In addition, the recipe is already weird with the repeated install appends. If we want to refactor it, we could do so separately?
